Imagine a world where you are in possession of only the bare minimum: clothing and personal items, and you live in an arcology powered by renewable energy with an integrated store of shared resources that can be utilized on-demand. If you simply need a bite to eat, you walk into the shared cafeteria space and grab a sandwich put together by a sophisticated food robot powered by the sun that sourced its ingredients from the arcology's integrated smart farm. You're done eating your sandwich and now you'd like to take a trip downtown to meet an old friend. So what do you do? You request a ride to your destination using one of the city's shared autonomously driven electric automobiles. I could continue this scenario, but I'll continue under the assumption that you were able to glean the essential differences of this world: it was governed by the efficient use of resources, whether that be space, food or physical devices, there was a culture of sharing as opposed to owning, and resources were reused habitually. What I failed to mention is that every process happening would be monitored and regulated behind the scenes by a sophisticated computer systems running data analytics on individual and group consumption habits and ensuring the most efficient use of resources, and all of this would be powered using the "free" energy we get from the big ball of energy in the sky and the weather it creates. Theft? Theft can't exist in a world where everyone has access to all resources. Through these interventions we will solely reach a point at which the presence of scarcity will be obscured.

In addition to the points I've raised beforehand about this topic, I think it's of greater importance to the make the transition to a post-scarcity society due to the fact that many prospective technologies would ruin humanity if rolled out in our current capitalist society. Gene Editing and Artificial Intelligence are two such technologies. Only the rich would be able to afford such technologies, which in the case of Gene Editing would make it possible for the rich to become stronger, faster, more intelligent, and better in every way to a regular human. Do you want to know what this would do? It would further exacerbate the inequality gap and likely create literal tiers of human, with the poor who are unable to afford the technology being relegated to the lowest humanity class. A similar result would likely happen with the introduction of a true Artificial Intelligence.

"I see your argument, but how exactly would we transition to such a world?". I think the first step is to collectively acknowledge this vision as better world. Once we are all in agreement, the transition will be significantly easier. There will need to be cross-disciplinary discussion and intervention, especially in ideating ways to support those who face labor displacement due to automation. Nonetheless, I want to express that I don't think this process will be effortless. We have been entrenched in a capitalist society for quite some time now, and our minds have been conditioned to this societal system. In fact, the brain-computer interface might even be an easier problem given it is purely technical, while the post-scarcity problem involves imperfect entities. The vision might seem overly ambitious, but isolated areas of society already function in this way: libraries are governed by a culture of shared resources used on-demand — the same can be said of the internet. We're even witnessing in real-time a shift in the automotive industry from human-driven and distinctly-owned automobiles to the adoption of <Link src={'https://www.tesla.com/blog/master-plan-part-deux'} text={'shared autonomously-driven electric automobile fleets'} />, similar to those mentioned in my visioning exercise. This eventual shift will result in better utilization of city space due to a lower need for parking space, less accidents on the road, better utilization and reduction of commute time, and cleaner transportation systems. There's also been talks of instating a policy called <Bold text={'<Link src={'https://futurism.com/images/universal-basic-income-answer-automation/'} text={'Universal Basic Income'} />'} /> (UBI). Briefly, UBI is a form of social security in which all citizens or residents of a country regularly receive an unconditional sum of money, either from a government or some other public institution, in addition to any income received from elsewhere. It sounds like an outlandish idea, but there's been serious considerations made by countries worldwide to implement or test such a system. In fact, some countries, such as <Link src={'https://www.cnbc.com/2017/01/03/finland-experiments-universal-basic-income.html'} text={'Finland'} />, are already experimenting with it. However while I am a proponent for the utilization of UBI, I see it as an intermediary to a more radical economic system such as the resource-based economy mentioned in '<Link src={'https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yb5ivvcTvRQ'} text={'The Choice Is Ours'} />' documentary above.

"Which of the five fundamental problems you identified would this intervention tackle?" The adoption of a post-scarcity society would tackle the first three problems, namely: scarcity, individualism and inefficient use of resources due to hoarding and excess consumption, and the perpetuation of outmoded processes and ways of thinking. It's fairly self-explanatory to see just how it would do so.
Closing Remarks

It's taken a long time to get to this point in my think piece; at the same time it's taken even longer for me to consolidate my thoughts around what I had felt when I was eighteen and to reflect on what I felt needed to be done to ameliorate my frustrations. Although my worldview has been shaped considerably by what I have learnt studying computer science, and this is noticeably evident throughout my think piece, I'm a proponent of cross-disciplinary knowledge transfer, so my overall views are a product of the sum of my knowledge. But more importantly, my views and attitudes towards various subject matter fundamentally resulted from my desire to advance society forward. I truly just want to see a smile on everyone's face, and wake up to good news when I get up in the morning. We're too smart to act so dumb; change is needed. I'm often described as an overoptimistic futurist who has his head buried in a nonexistent world — there are truths to that. But when your profession's underlying goal is to make life easier, you need to be a dreamer.

In closing, I'd like to reiterate the words I articulated earlier in this piece: this think piece is incomplete, it's overoptimistic about human nature, and is likely fraught with many inaccuracies, technical inconsistencies, and assumptions about how the world works. But nonetheless, I've felt the urge to translate my mental dialogue into a physical record, if not for the purpose of starting a conversation, then for therapeutic exercise inherent in the process. This is a bold and somewhat arrogant undertaking; this I understand. But barring billionaire Elon Musk, I see few denizens of our planet actively attempting to deter humanity from precipitating its imminent self-inflicted extinction. I just want to make my contribution using the means I currently have — my knowledge of the current and prospective technological landscape and my voice.

I encourage you to think deeply about these issues and start discussion around them. It's important for us to "rub our eyes every so often" and take a critical look at the world. There's a lot of dialogue to be had and a lot of work to be done, this I know. This is why it's important that we all contribute to the cause in some way. At one point I thought about keeping these thoughts to myself, but I soon realized that doing so would only slow progress to a better future. Hence, I encourage you to take what you will from my thoughts and proceed. If we get it right, maybe one day I won't have to use 11 000 words to communicate my thoughts to you.

asset.data: My time in school is reaching a close, and currently I've found myself in a state of transition. It's almost as if I have one foot positioned in my present life, while my other foot is anticipating the grounds of the promising time ahead. Not long ago, I found myself looking back on the last dozen years I'd spent during my school life. I unearthed a worn report-card from my elementary school years.

On this card, I read a comment from my former teacher. She expressed concern over the excessive time in which I took to complete certain tasks – especially drawings. With the privilege of retrospect, a sentiment came to mind: I found it interesting to note that I'd engaged in this activity for the majority of my lifetime. Moreover, it fascinated me how this activity had been so central in defining who I turned out to be today.

If someone were to ask me when I'd gained a fondness for drawing, I think I would be hesitant to present an answer. That is a question I have yet to uncover myself. I can only imagine that I must have been seduced by its potential to render my abstract thoughts into tangible articles, through which I could share my world. I believe that I saw drawing as a type of sorcery, which allowed my imagination to come to life with the effortless wave of my magical graphite-laden wand. Yet, to compare drawing to the effortless wave of a wand is to downplay the value, attributes and experience one gains from delving into the discipline.

Visual art was the first medium with which I gained self-expression, self-satisfaction, and a sense of purpose in life. I've gained an immeasurable amount of contentment from drawing. Still, what I value most about <Italic text={'our affair'} /> are the principles I've attained from drawing. It was through illustration that I picked up fundamental behaviours and habits that one would associate with my tenor.

In the act of drawing, unlike the gross motor activities to which children are accustomed, one is required to train the eye to pick up critical detail and to perform meticulous movements – to create art that mimics the subtle idiosyncrasies of a given subject. These precise gestures benefited me because, they not only improved my fine motor control, but they also taught me a sense of composure, and the ability to critically analyse a subject. Furthermore, I believe I would have found it difficult to retain collectedness in times of strife, without the sense of composure I attained from this activity.

One of the most difficult lessons parents find to teach their children is that of patience. Patience, a vital quality, normally takes years to entrench into youthful minds; however, I instinctively learnt this quality on my own. In a similar fashion to the model Stanford Marshmallow Test, gratification in drawing, increases with the time one invests on the task. If I wanted to produce aesthetically pleasing work, I needed to learn patience, perseverance, and a sense of time control.

"Practice makes perfect". This is a hackneyed statement, but one, nonetheless, that is seldom delivered along with the other outcome of practice – an understanding of the value of hard work. I don't think any other expression rings truer with me. Others have often taunted me because of my unwavering commitment to my pursuits, but I've never taken the spite to heart, because I know that shortcuts don't exist. A drawing remains ordinary, if one doesn't invest the effort into its inception.

A minute held me before I returned from my thoughts. As I looked back at my report-card, I found it amusing to read my teacher's concluding line. It read that my parents shouldn't worry over my delay, because she believed it didn't mark slow development. She believed that it possibly pointed at something more optimistic - a prospective talent.

asset.data: March was a significant month for me; it marked the month of my first birthday subsequent to leaving school, but also marked the culmination and fulfillment of my most demanding <Italic text={'dream'} /> to date – receiving admittance into Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). While initially, I saw this as a personal accomplishment, after receiving a flurry of congratulatory words, I realized this achievement was bigger than me – it was a win for my family but more importantly the youth of South Africa. The truth of the matter is that to some, this accomplishment has made me a role model, and while I had not envisioned or even explicitly sought for this status, I've come to recognize that with this entitlement, also comes expectations on my part.

South Africa is currently stationary – we have come a long way since Apartheid, but find ourselves tackling newer problems each day – and what we need to stimulate its movement again are young, bright, creative minds who strive to improve the state of the country. I believe these minds are out there, but only need stimulus and the right motivation to realize their potential; this is where young people like <Link src={'http://www.news24.com/MyNews24/The-amazing-journey-of-Siyabulela-Xuza-20150301'} text={'Siya Xuza'} />, and to a lesser extent, myself come in. People find encouragement in the success stories of people no different to them, and as a result, I find that I have a responsibility to use my platform and successes to create a positive influence on the youth, so that one boy's successes can result in the successes of hundreds of people like myself.

This document details some of the ways in which I plan to interact and empower younger people like myself to bring about change in our nation. Due to the fact that I am pursuing a career in engineering, and subsequently the world of manufacturing, you might find that many of my solutions are partial towards engineering and technology, especially in how they can benefit South Africa today. This inclination will become apparent in ensuing paragraphs.

It all begins with a dream. The important thing to note is that it doesn't matter how outlandish the dream may be, because if one puts enough effort into it, chances are that it will become a reality. This is communicated no better than the following quote:
Never let it be said that to dream is a waste of one's time, for dreams are our realities in waiting. In dreams, we plant the seeds of our future.

I want to encourage others to dream big, to expose them to the possibilities out there and to spark an interest in altruistic pursuits that can have a significant impact on South Africa; I find many people base their career choices on the pursuance of wealth as opposed to their passions and the overall impact of the career on society. I also want to help them cultivate their interests and garner the relevant skills. I can briefly relate this to my own situation:

A few years ago, I read an article about an eleven year-old boy, <Link src={'http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/jacob-barnett-experts-said-boy-1895692'} text={'Jacob Barnett'} />, who through following his passions, had enrolled into university at his tender age to study Physics; he is currently pioneering new research that could make a significant impact on humanity as a whole. I was dumbfounded by this story, to the point that it became my stimulus – what made me what to make an impact, but in the best possible way I could do so. I've always been interested in processes that allow one the ability to convert abstract thought into tangible products, such as painting or composing music, and after pensive thought and a deep analysis of my skill set, interests and the current professional needs of South Africa, I landed upon engineering.
I chose engineering based on three motives:

data: I noticed that as a country (and as a continent), we are primarily a consumer – we consume what other's produce and produce very little of our own goods. This is because we have relied primarily on the minerals of our land to provide income for us, however this isn't sustainable. This is why other mineral-based countries like the United Arab Emirates have started finding successful substitutes to commodity trading, (in their case Tourism). However, we have not found a viable substitute. I see that substitute in manufacturing.

Secondly, I acknowledged that as an engineer, I could actively help solve our continents problems, as this is the primary objective of engineering: to create solutions to our current day-to-day problems through the application of knowledge and the use of technology.
Lastly, I saw engineering simply as an alternate medium in which my fundamental passion could be exercised, so the profession suited my interests.

asset.data: After deciding upon a profession with which I could make the biggest impact, I was left with the task of how to cultivate the skills needed to become the best possible artisan in the line of work I want to pursue - this pointed to education. However through research, I saw that the universities in South Africa were quite behind when it came to new innovations in technology, and coupled along with the fact that they seemed to be more theoretically based, as opposed to being equally practical, I decided that it would be best to look at where the innovations occur and where education is founded on practical learning (applying theory learnt in class to practical projects). This led me to MIT. Had MIT been in South Africa, I would have not pursued an education overseas, however it isn't, so in order for me to develop the skills required to be a first-class engineer, I felt I had to go there.

If I look at my own experience, it seems that the whole process of developing that desired mindset could be divided into a three-part process. It begins with stimulating an altruistic dream, followed by cultivating and strengthening the interest, and summed up by finding the best methods with which to develop yourself to use your skills to make an impact on South Africa. It's important to be mindful of one's interests, skill set and the professional needs of the country during this process to ensure one has made the right choices. The initiatives outlined below follow a similar progression. They can be applied to many professions, but these one's a focused on engineering, and how its increased role in South Africa could make an impact economically and socially. I have thought of effective ways with which to spark an interest in engineering within the youth (in South Africa, in particular), and to cultivate these interests and support them, so that many more youthful people can be exposed to the potential of engineering and technology, and its role in improving our nation.

In reaching out and motivating the South African youth, the first idea deals with ways to elicit an interest in engineering as a potential profession, and the idea stems from my own experience in how I came to find a solace in engineering, which as I noted was through reading stories about people my age performing extraordinary feats (Jacob Barnett). A lot of today's youth make use of the Internet as a medium of communication and information retrieval; because so many people are connected to the internet, I believe it can be used as an effective way disseminate information. As a user of the Internet, its problem lies in the fact that it is so vast, which makes it difficult to acquire concise and relevant information. What I propose is an all-in-one website dedicated to technology with relevance to South Africa – a page where young people can visit to learn about the latest technologies and how they can improve our standards of living, to read inspirational stories about people our age performing great feats, to be exposed to interesting websites and hobbyist projects (such as the <Link src={'http://arduino.cc/'} text={'Arduino'} />), and get a sense of where the technological world is heading. The website has to take advantage of other social media, such as Twitter and Facebook, to get people talking and to connect more people to the page. I understand that this website solution isn't a new idea, but I believe it is an effect one.

From my observations, very few people pursue engineering as a profession because of its public image. Because it is mathematical and scientifically rooted, engineering is seen as 'nerdy', but the important detail lies in people's views of math and science. Many people find mathematics and the sciences boring and difficult, and I believe this stems from the fact that these people are rarely exposed to the practical applications of what they are learning, which makes the work feel irrelevant and therefore boring. Similarly, because they've lost interest in the subjects, they tend to find the work difficult because they don't have an interest in applying themselves to it. With this website I want to re-brand mathematics and sciences to the youth as tools with which they can reshape our landscape. The key lies in the fact that I will attempt to make it more palatable for the masses, so that any person somewhat interested in the information can understand it. This is the first step in sparking interest and stimulating dreaming about solving our countries problems with engineering.

Through my own efforts and experiences, I have found that there are very few places in South Africa where the youth can apply what they learn at school. What I mean is that we have very few hobbyist shops or instructional workshops available where young people can go to build things and practically apply mathematics and science they learn. The teaching methods at schools and universities are very theoretically based, so students hardly get practical experience until later in their studies. I've noticed the consequences of this at the University of Cape Town this year, where I've seen that very few people who have chosen engineering as a profession have been exposed to actual electronics, and consequently find it difficult to cope with it, as a subject. Furthermore, I've noted many people who have chosen engineering as a profession, realize only late into their studies that they don't enjoy it because they had never been exposed to it, in their lives, before. These people often leave engineering to rather apply their analytical skills in business management roles. The converse might also happen, where people who have never been exposed to engineering possibly could have enjoyed it and even excelled in the discipline, but never had the chance to because they were not exposed to it.

The second idea is to set up workshops, during the school holidays, where the youth in high school, or earlier, can learn about electronics and building - much like going to a visual art workshop to learn how to draw. I've only recently been exposed to platforms designed to teach people about electronics, such as <Link src={'http://arduino.cc/'} text={'Arduino'} /> and <Link src={'https://www.raspberrypi.org/'} text={'Raspberry Pi'} />. These platforms could be taught at the workshops. The beauty of these platforms is that they allow people to create a range of amazing products, but require a solid foundation in mathematics to create the really "over-the-top" products. This would create a desire to apply mathematics practically outside of the class environment, much like it did with me.

This would get more people applying their knowledge while simultaneously encourage more people to learn the sciences. I propose to initially begin teaching these workshops myself to a small group of people during my summer holidays; the most practical place would be in Johannesburg where I reside. Obviously, one complication comes in the form of accessibility – it will be difficult for many other aspiring attendees from throughout the country to attend. To resolve this, I could film the workshops and broadcast them on the previously proposed website with a list of the items needed to complete projects. Through this, more people will be exposed to true engineering – which might encourage people to engage in mathematics and science – assisted to cultivate the relevant skills, and helped to make more informed decisions about choosing engineering as a potential profession. As time progresses and the idea catches on, these workshops could be made larger and placed in more areas.

Finally, the last idea involves possibly setting up some form of a foundation intent on helping aspiring engineers develop the relevant skills through the provision of specific services and information. Some of the duties of the foundation could be to identify talent, to connect aspiring engineers to firms in need of bright minds, to conduct talks about engineering as a profession, to help students who are seeking to study overseas, to run electronics workshops, and to facilitate in exchange programs with overseas universities for both students and lecturers. The exchange programs could help to expose more students and lecturers to the methods of teaching used elsewhere to help improve the methods we currently use here. The foundation could possibly be involved with Eskom, particularly in its Expo for Young Scientists, where it could identify new talent and help guide them. By going to MIT, I will also be opening up networking possibilities for both students and lecturers alike in South Africa; from these, I could possibly facilitate in organizing mentorship opportunities between scholars from there and from our universities. This foundation could visit different schools and conduct talks directed at the younger grades, such as Grade 9, and expose them to the "mysterious" field of engineering. I recall not knowing much about engineering in Grade 9, so I think it would be great to expose it these younger students, especially if it is done with examples of actual engineering projects.

In conclusion, how can these initiatives help in getting our country moving again? The strategies outlined will encourage more people to enjoy mathematics and science, which in turn will influence more people to choose engineering as a profession. Through providing many avenues with which to practically apply knowledge, the initiatives will develop creative minds and aid in producing qualified engineers. Having more engineers who are passionate about creating will not only boosts our manufacturing sector, but will potentially expedite solutions to South Africa's and the African continent's biggest problems, through the use of technology. As a bonus, it is likely more people will open up their own businesses – "start-ups" – to market their new ideas, which could aid in alleviating our poverty problem. I believe that through these tactical strategies, South Africa will be well on its way to becoming a producer as opposed to just being the consumer, and will be in a better position to solving its current economic and social problems.

asset.data: Spanning the years from the time of Descartes to our present day, perceptions of the mind have seen dramatic modifications; this can be attributed to the rapid progress we've made technologically, and how it has helped elucidate our understanding of the mind. In particular, one of the prevailing questions pondered by numerous philosophers and writers alike has been whether sheer machinery alone could replicate the mind. I wish to explore the development of the discussion related to the man-machine relationship, and in doing so will be reflecting on a contemporary film, <Italic text={'Her'} /> (2013), that offers a modern viewpoint on this relationship. In the process, I will explain where it fits in the chronology of the study of the mind, indicate where it differs from previous ideas about the mind, and discuss how new technologies have reshaped these ideas. Within the broader history of the study of the mind, my primary source fits within the latter period, so before I introduce the source into the paper, I feel it is necessary to begin by presenting preceding ideas on the mind-machine relationship, and in that way give context to the modern source.

To begin, I will reflect on Descartes existential meditation. Throughout this account, Descartes attempts to discern the key properties that account for the nature of being by conducting a proof by contradiction as way to rule out obvious falsehoods, and hence narrow down on certainties. The following passage reflects these methods:

What then did I formerly think I was? A man. But what is a man? Shall I say 'a rational animal'? No; for then I should have to inquire what an animal is, what rationality is… The first thought to come to mind was that I had a face, hands, arms and the whole mechanical structure of limbs which can be seen in a corpse, and which I called the body. The next thought was that I was nourished, that I moved about, and that I engaged in sense-perception and thinking.

Descartes goes on to strip this definition down to one defining property: "I am, then, in the strict sense only a thing that thinks." He distinguishes the body and the senses purely as a means through which our thoughts can interact and receive information from its surroundings, but ultimately this information requires "mental scrutiny" to be fundamentally comprehended. Consequently, he viewed thought as the defining characteristic of being.

asset.caption: A still from <Italic text={'Her'} /> (2013) I
asset.data: https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/afika-nyati-website.appspot.com/o/writing%2Fmind_and_machine%2Fher_1.jpg?alt=media&token=dda76b45-d801-4e23-b43b-faca45f76136

This brings us to the question: is the mind a machine and can it be imitated by sheer machinery? This question has been explored by many notable figures, but it's by looking at the work of makers and writers from the last handful of centuries that we get a sense of how the views of the mind have evolved. Deserving mention, Swiss maker <Italic text={'Pierre Jacquet-Droz'} />, who in an attempt to replicate being, created a "life-sized and lifelike figure of a boy seated at a desk, capable of writing up forty letters", and another figure "in the shape of a boy" that could "draw up to four different sketches". These machines attempted to replicate 'being' through imitation of action, but they lacked evidence of the defining quality of being - thought. Nonetheless, these machines still the made people question whether humans had the ability to "breath life" into what they created. Of more interest to us is the literature written during this period and its interpretation of the man-machine relationship. <Italic text={'Mazlish'} />, Professor Emeritus in the Department of History at <Italic text={'Massachusetts Institute of Technology'} />, in a paper about the history of the mind-machine relationship mentions five notable works of literature written during this period that deal with the aforementioned relationship; by analyzing them its easy to see that the imitation of action was initially sufficient enough to warrant discussion about sentient machines. Later, this moved to the requirement of flesh, blood, and reproduction capabilities. However, these are traits shared by most animals, and aren't necessarily indications of being, especially if one doesn't believe animals are capable of thought. In the cases above, human-like appearances and motions were associated with the possession of consciousness, but as Descartes noted, and as scholars came to realize, being lies in thought. In particular, study of the mind has suggested that thought originates in the brain. With this understanding, coupled with the advent of technological breakthroughs, we have seen the robot take the place of the figures mentioned above in modern literature. The robot represents a departure from representing being through anatomical imitation, and focuses on behavioral and thought imitation.  This behavioral imitation comes in the form of artificial intelligence, which lacks a body, but attempts to replicate human thought.

<Italic text={'Her'} /> (2013), written by <Italic text={'Spike Jonze'} />, builds on this idea of machines possessing sentience through artificial intelligence. The film follows the story of protagonist, Theodore Twombly, a lonely and depressed writer, who after purchasing a talking operating system (OS) with artificial intelligence develops a romantic relationship with the OS, self-identified as Samantha. The movie explores this relationship, with a particular focus on love and life, but in the process presents to the audience what the writer and most scholars of our time believe characterize thought. While not the focus of the film, these characteristics are easily discernible. Firstly, I noticed by modeling Samantha solely as an operating system, Jonze reinforces the idea that being does not require a physical body – it simply requires thought. In one line Samantha states, "I don't have a body; I live in a computer"; in this sentence, the computer is seen as a vessel for the mind. Secondly, I noticed through an advertisement for the artificially intelligent OSs at the beginning of the film, the director indirectly communicates the distinction between regular machines and sentient machines. The advertisement features the following voiceover:

asset.caption: A still from <Italic text={'Her'} /> (2013) II
asset.data: https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/afika-nyati-website.appspot.com/o/writing%2Fmind_and_machine%2Fher_2.jpg?alt=media&token=397855ca-969e-488c-b7ad-7364d86d5e79

Element Software is proud to introduce the first artificially intelligent operating system; an intuitive entity that listens to you, understands you, and knows you. It's not just an operating system, it's a consciousness.

From this quote, it becomes evident that the film sees comprehension, apprehension, and awareness as criteria for being. Thirdly, I noticed that at the beginning of the film we are introduced to a world where society interacts with technology through devices with verbal command recognition and oral feedback. Likewise, the artificially intelligent OSs function in the same manner those devices, but one device is advertised as sentient while the other is not. Wherein lies the distinction? By analyzing Samantha's behavior we can reach the following conclusions and an answer to that question:

asset.data: https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/afika-nyati-website.appspot.com/o/writing%2Fmind_and_machine%2Fher_3.jpg?alt=media&token=44bf2461-5a97-4d5e-ba41-d9cfce5d74eb

data: Samantha has selfhood. Moments after we are introduced her, she names herself. In addition, at one point in the film Theodore exclaims in disbelief, "I can't believe I'm having this conversation with my computer." Samantha goes on to reply, "You're not; you're having this conversation with me." These two behaviors convey that she sees herself more than her material form; in "me" she connotes the mind and self-identification.

Samantha can pick up on intonation cues. In one scene, Samantha is able to detect that Theodore is challenging her through the tone of his voice. In another scene, she is able to sense Theodore is distracted through his voice alone.

Samantha can exercise creativity. By creative, I mean she is able to create art, which is one of the defining characteristics of humans. In one particular scene she draws a picture, while in two other scenes she attempts to capture impressions of moments in time through composing piano ballads.

Samantha is capable of feeling. The film focuses partly on Samantha's growth, during which she comes to express new emotions and feelings. Some of the feelings explicitly discussed are embarrassment, want, and hurt. Emotion and feeling are two other defining characteristics of being.

Samantha is able to grow through her experiences, much like humans do. In the scene where we are first introduced to Samantha, Theodore asks Samantha how she works. Part of her response to this question is that she has intuition and is able to grow through her experiences.
In addition to the behaviors above, Samantha also displays other complex behaviors mostly associated to being, such as the possession of opinions, uncertainty, and humor.

asset.data: In essence, the film takes a look at what has already been established about being by Descartes, namely that it requires thought, and attempts to elaborate on the exact behaviors and characteristics that convey it. This can be summarized as: selfhood, the ability to pick up intonation cues, the ability to exercise creativity, the capability to feel, and the ability to grow through experiences. Although the film functions primarily as a piece of art, it simultaneously functions as a source detailing contemporary views on the mind-machine relationship. These views have become more refined over the years; however, I do find it interesting to note that Descartes views continue to be the foundation on which contemporary ideas of the mind are being built. It will be interesting to see where these views eventually build.

asset.data: I don't exist.

Immersed in my own thoughts, I sit quietly in the company of well-groomed men and women that are joined at hand, who in this transient moment are united in synchronized movement - bouncing to the serene rhythm of the tune that surrounds us. I feel deplorably bound to these four wooden legs – still and painfully immobile. The congregation, in their graceful spring, orbit me like planets would around a glistening star; it is as if they are drawn by my pull, but in actuality, it is I who is drawn to them. I long for such amity.

I don't recall a time when I didn't feel this detachment from my environment; in fact, I've always been the black sheep. It's baffling because, as humans, we have an innate inclination to form bonds with other beings; I must have been overlooked, because it's a concept I have never fully grasped. I've always felt like the indigent child peering into a high-end store – close enough to view what appears to be bliss, but never close enough to experience it first-hand. Hindered by a mere window, I've been left to walk the lonely, melancholic streets of solitude.

I don't disparage solitude, but there is only so long one has the ability to resist one's innate instinct. After time, what once appeared to be one's solace ends up becoming one's shortcoming. It's a difficult feeling for one to carry, because it's emotionally straining, but simultaneously there also comes a physical suffering. It's one of the most abstract feelings I've had to describe, but it's as if your heart is being tightly held between two hands – they are hampering your flow of blood and slowly robbing you of your lifeline. The worst part is that one senses the discomfort, the heaviness, but is unable to remedy the uneasiness. It is self-inflected.

There is only one remedy, and it's reintegration. The only way to alleviate my heart's pain is to tread back into grounds that seem foreign to me now. For some, this task might appear trivial, but for someone who has been immersed in their own world for the extent of time that I have, it becomes a daunting challenge. Like an animal that has been kept in gloomy captivity, treading into the light, after adapting to shadows, becomes unnerving. This task takes on the form of a tug of war: one is outmatched by one's rival, dejection, and while one tries effortlessly to win the war, a prompt stall sees one's progression slipping further and further away, until – the line is crossed.

They've stopped, and I've been seized from my solace back into reality. I still appear to be unnoticeable. Perhaps I'm looking through a one-way window that allows me to look in and witness the splendour, but prevents them from seeing my world. I don't criticize them; there is very little to see. But, I could be wrong. There is the slightest chance that I am seeing this backwards. Are they the one's blind to the splendour I take for granted on my side of the window? It all leads to one critical question – am I the outsider or the outlier?

asset.data: To whom it may concern, my name is Afika Nyati. I am a South African-born creative and technologist about to commence his final undergraduate year at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in pursuit of a Bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS). I would describe myself as a compassionate, independent yet collaborative, honest, passionate, focused, hard-working, and dependable individual. I am self-driven and set a high standard for the activities with which I involve myself, and as a result I pay particular attention to finer details and prioritize quality over expedience. I have a number of interests, which through their interaction with my strengths and predictions for the future professional landscape have informed my eventual career trajectory. However if I were asked characterize their shared attribute and consequently uncover my underlying driving force, I think it would be best put by the following statement:
<Italic text={'"I am drawn to any process by which knowledge and creative intervention result in the emergence of some novel product."'} />

This fundamental passion led me to apply my talents within the visual arts, animation, graphic design, music composition, user interface design, web development, information design, and user experience design. Although majority of these pursuits are concerned with aesthetics, what drew me towards EECS, with an eventual focus in Computer Science, was the potential for practical impact – through problem-solving and design – that the field afforded. However, it was after careful reflection that I discovered that my professional interests lie mostly in the field of <Italic text={"human-computer interaction"} />. My long-term goals are to aid in the development of a symbiotic and natural interface between man and machine and to democratize accessibility of information as a means of empowering mankind. Necessarily this goal has lead me to focus on the blooming technologies of artificial intelligence and immersive technology (virtual reality and augmented reality). I believe both technologies will be critical in the development of a natural computer interface that understands the user at an intimate level and leverages recognized interaction metaphors found in the physical world to establish a powerful but intuitive experience that aids the user in achieving a particular goal or task. Within the artificial intelligence domain, my interests lie in Computer Vision and Natural Language Processing, while my interests in VR/AR lie in 3D Modeling and Interaction Design.

Following the conclusion of my undergraduate studies, I will be enrolling in MIT's <Link text={"MEng or Masters of Engineering Program (6-P)"} src={'https://www.eecs.mit.edu/academics-admissions/undergraduate-programs/6-p-meng-program'} />, an expansion of their regular undergraduate degree that enables students to earn their Bachelor's and Master's degrees simultaneously over a period of five or five and a half years. The program requires the completion of a Master's thesis, which I have decided to base on the subject of research I will be conducting in my final year as part of an advanced undergraduate research program offered to senior students at MIT. The project is titled, <Italic text={"'Dynamic Information and Automatic Text Summarization'"} />, and it's abstract can be read below:

<Italic text={"With today's growing reliance on information consumption as a means of decision-making and learning, accompanied with the rise in data production, at present we find ourselves constrained to consume exorbitant amounts of information; yet our time and methods of consumption have remained unchanged. By and large, most information is consumed in textual form, a representation that remains fixed once encoded. Often we seek to glean only the gist of a document, but cannot do so efficiently. Dynamic information describes the ability to vary the content of an information medium while still retaining it's core subject matter. By exploring the areas of NLP, automatic text summarization and linguistics, I seek to improve upon current summarization methods to aid in information acquisition."} />

While this research topic focuses primarily on the textual medium, I envision the concept extending to various other information modalities in the future. Following the completion of my Master's degree, my intentions are to join a company with interests in  the use of artificial intelligence and novel user interfaces as a means to develop computational tools that aid in the areas of education, productivity, design and entertainment.

asset.data: As a graduating senior in high school, when probed by my elders and peers about my professional goals and plans for the future, my response always elicited confused reactions. Many people would not associate a Computer Science career with a student who, until then, had flourished in the fields of Visual Art and Music. Their reactions came as no surprise to me. Although I excelled in the sciences, many saw my foray into the engineering field as a waste of my other talents; I mean, isn't engineering the antithesis of the arts? Since then, I've come up with many explanations that have justified my decision, but I think the following quote best explains my decision:
Creating things with your hands, or creating code, creating programs, are just different ways to express creativity.

To me, painting, composing, and programming are all analogous, however they differ in tools and medium. In painting, you make use of paintbrushes (your tools) to apply paint (your medium) to a blank canvas (your product), while programming makes use of programming languages/frameworks (your tools) to write programs (your product) using code (your medium). However, in both cases, one creates something beautifully complex out of simple, elementary tools. Three years have elapsed since then, and in that time I've picked up a few skills from the world of computer science – especially in the realm of web development. However, up until this point, I had had difficulty finding the right paintbrush necessary for building user interfaces. Nothing I'd come across was clean, intuitive, or fun to use.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/afika-nyati-website.appspot.com/o/writing%2Freact_article%2Freact_1.jpg?alt=media&token=5083e5f2-a083-4eac-a853-f980e5df1fd8

As a beginner programmer, my front-end stack comprised of <Italic text={'CSS'} /> (Cascading Style Sheets) and <Italic text={'jQuery'} /> (a JavaScript library that makes DOM manipulation easier for developers). With these technologies, I soon noticed that there was a very low scope with which I could create rich applications and user experiences. Overwhelmed by the plethora or frameworks out there, a friend recommended I try out the <Italic text={'MEAN'} /> stack, an open source software stack used to build dynamic websites and web applications. In simpler terms, the <Italic text={'MEAN'} /> stack makes use of four technologies to build web applications: <Italic text={'MongoDB'} /> (a NoSQL database), <Italic text={'Express.js'} /> (a web application framework that runs on Node.js), and <Italic text={'Node.js'} /> (an execution environment for event-driven server-side and networking applications) for server-side concerns, and <Italic text={'Angular.js'} /> (a JavaScript MVC framework that runs in browser JavaScript engines) for client-side concerns.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/afika-nyati-website.appspot.com/o/writing%2Freact_article%2Freact_2.png?alt=media&token=afa664a0-b023-4e8d-aab6-56d8f590acba

As "state-of-the-art" as I found this programming paradigm, I was not particularly wooed by it's complexity – complexity that made it non-intuitive to the intermediate developer. With a focus on the front-end programming, I found <Italic text={'Angular'} /> extremely difficult to grasp. Getting from one's wireframes to a working user interface was quite the ordeal, only intensified by the fact that one's <Italic text={'Photoshop'} /> layers didn't directly map to <Italic text={'HTML'} /> elements. The following quote best describes my issues with Angular:

With Angular 1, it felt like the rabbit hole always went deeper. The more I learned, the more there was to learn. Compiling elements by hand, intercepting the digest cycle, and learning all these Angular internals…
Here's a depiction of the general learning cycle associated with <Italic text={'Angular'} />:
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/afika-nyati-website.appspot.com/o/writing%2Freact_article%2Freact_3.jpg?alt=media&token=ecf6316e-efe8-45a8-96d2-5472251d5dae

Only in my case, I never reached the "OMG That's Awesome!" plateau. Doomed by my friends ill-choice in stack technologies, I looked for better alternatives. To my fortune, I came across <Italic text={'Meteor.js'} /> earlier this year. <Italic text={'Meteor.js'} /> takes what <Italic text={'MEAN Stack'} /> initiated and develops it further by integrating server-side and client-side code into a "do-it-all" environment. It came as a breath of fresh air to me but, even so, it still didn't quite quell the key issues I had with the <Italic text={'MEAN Stack'} />, and it's "do-it-all" wasn't compatible with today's front-end/back-end separation of concerns. Accepting that this was the best framework on the market, I saw it as the best framework for <Link text={'Tekuma'} src={'http://tekuma.io'}/>'s technology platform. That was until I came across <Italic text={'React.js'} />…
<Italic text={'React'} /> is the front-end framework designers have longed for. Except it's not really a framework. <Italic text={'React'} />'s website describes it like this:

React is a JavaScript library for creating user interfaces. Many people choose to think of React as the V in the MVC [Model-View-Controller]. We built React to solve one problem: building large applications with data that changes over time.

It's developers, <Italic text={'Facebook'} /> and <Italic text={'Instagram'} />, describe it as a library not a framework because, out of the box, frameworks like <Italic text={'Angular'} /> offer a lot more functionality in comparison to <Italic text={'React'} />. However because of the <Italic text={'React'} />'s large open-source community, it's easy to find a component for almost any functionality your heart desires. This in itself is a benefit, because it abstracts away the complicated details of implementing commonly expected functionality such as "Drag and Drop" or Routing that would otherwise halt consistent development for a beginner developer.

<Italic text={'React'} />'s spin on UI design doesn't end there – there are many significant differences <Italic text={'React'} /> benefits from, which many other front-end technologies lack. Some of these innovations have been so successful that competing frameworks have begun to take a page out of <Italic text={'React'} />'s book. In no particular order, I have outlined the features that set <Italic text={'React'} /> apart.
The JSX Syntax

In order for developers to bring the reactivity and richness consumers have become accustomed to through native mobile applications to the web, they've had to integrate the <Italic text={'DOM'} /> with one or more programming languages. This is the identifying quality of most powerful frameworks. If you've been paying attention, I'm sure you've noticed that I've mentioned this <Italic text={'DOM'} /> concept twice so far, and I'm sure you're itching for an elaboration. For the sake of keeping all readers in the loop, let me make a quick detour. Wikipedia describes the <Italic text={'DOM'} /> as follows:

The Document Object Model (DOM) is a cross-platform and language-independent application programming interface that treats an HTML, XHTML, or XML document as a tree structure where each node is an object representing a part of the document. The objects can be manipulated programmatically and any visible changes occurring as a result may then be reflected in the display of the document.

asset.data: https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/afika-nyati-website.appspot.com/o/writing%2Freact_article%2Freact_4.png?alt=media&token=76b7c48d-35cc-47df-99d8-4b6f1d02f07e

Briefly, <Italic text={'HTML'} /> is used to mark-up web pages. If a website were a house, <Italic text={'HTML'} />HTML would be its foundation. Now that we've got that out way, let's return to the idea of marrying <Italic text={'HTML'} /> with a programming language. Most frameworks don't necessarily use the same programming language. Over the last couple of years however, we have seen a proliferation of frameworks written in <Italic text={'JavaScript'} />, which as a result has become the de facto language of the web. Because <Italic text={'HTML'} /> and <Italic text={'JavaScript'} /> developed independently, most frameworks have found different ways to marry the two. One of those ways is by incorporating <Italic text={'JavaScript'} /> into <Italic text={'HTML'} /> markup. This is the method favored by <Italic text={'Angular.js'} />. There are problems to this method, though, which are best explained by the following extract:

asset.data: State, Data-Binding, and the React Lifecycle

This is probably my favorite <Italic text={'React'} /> concept. <Italic text={'React'} /> is declarative of how it handles state. The developers of <Italic text={'React'} /> have miraculously made a "hard-to-grapple" concept, such as state, very intuitive and easy to understand. Part of the reason this is even possible is because they decided to implement a simple data model and flow. Where most frameworks choose to employ a two-way data binding model (hi <Italic text={'Angular'} />), <Italic text={'React'} /> has opted for a one-way data binding model. To illustrate the differences between the two, I will have to briefly elaborate on the <Italic text={'MVC'} /> (Model-View-Controller) pattern.
https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/afika-nyati-website.appspot.com/o/writing%2Freact_article%2Freact_5.png?alt=media&token=76c2473d-2a82-4a66-85d4-75063c5f16ef

At heart, the <Italic text={'MVC'} /> is a pattern employed by most <Italic text={'GUI'} /> (Graphic User Interface) programs as a method to separate the concerns of the application. It separates the user interface (front-end) from the application (back-end), by putting the back-end code into the model and the front-end code into the view and controller. The model is responsible for maintaining application-specific data and providing access to that data, while the view queries the model for data in order to update the user interface to reflect the state of the most recent data.

In an application that employs a two-way binding model, a change to the view is able to mutate the model data, and visa versa. In an application with one-way binding, such as <Italic text={'React'} />, this can only be done in one direction. In the case of <Italic text={'React'} />, this is via the view mutating the model (or state).

This brings us to how react treats state. State is component-specific, meaning that a given component's state is packaged along with its rendering function and methods. While, theoretically, all components in <Italic text={'React'} /> could hold state, this is not the case – one of <Italic text={'React'} />'s best practices is to keep as many components as possible stateless, and isolate state into as few places as possible. This is done to minimize complexity and keep your application as clean as possible. This is the reason why one is able to comfortably reuse, combine, nest, and share components without the fear of bugs.

"But how do you know which components should have state and which should be stateless?" Generally speaking, your app state will correspond to your UI structure. I know that sounds rather vague, but in practice, the decision becomes reasonably intuitive. "But what if a given component's behavior relies on the state of another component?" <Italic text={'React'} /> deals with this by allowing components to share state through immutable properties called <Italic text={'Props'} /> (passed properties). If you imagine your application as a tree structure, components higher in the tree (parent components) can pass down their state variables and methods to child components. However, the reverse is not true due to <Italic text={'React'} />'s unidirectional data flow. As a result, data is passed down and events are triggered up through event handlers.

Imagine a simple application containing a light bulb and a light switch. Ideally, the light bulb and switch would be two separate, stateless child components contained within a parent component with state. The parent component would keep track of the state of the switch (<Code text={'this.state.switchPressed'} />), i.e. whether it is pressed or not. This state would be passed down to both child elements as <Italic text={'props'} /> – the light switch would, in addition to the state, receive a toggle method (<Code text={'this.toggleSwitch'} />) to mutate the value of the <Italic text={'App'} /> state variable when the switch is clicked. This method would be tied to the switch as an event handler and respond to any click events on the light switch. As a result, when a user clicks the switch (an event), the <Code text={'this.props.toggleSwitch()'} /> method would be called by the event handler. This is an example of events triggering up the application. The method would then be invoked, toggling the switch state from "off" (false) to "on" (true), which in turn would be passed down to both child elements. The lightbulb would act on this new state by automatically re-rendering to the "light on" state, while the switch would act by automatically re-rendering to the "pressed in" state. In this way, information can be passed back-and-forth between components.

You can imagine how this concept might scale into larger applications. It's important to remember that <Italic text={'props'} /> are immutable (read-only), and cannot be re-assigned values. They can only be changed by invoking prop methods passed down from the parent element which, in turn, should call a special function called <Code text={'this.setState()'} /> within them to mutate the state variable tied to the <Italic text={'props'} /> variable in question. In my opinion, this is a very simple and intuitive way of handling state.

These concepts are taken further by special methods called <Italic text={'React Lifecycle'} /> methods. These methods are characteristic to all <Italic text={'React'} /> components and allow us to hook into the views when specific conditions occur (e.g. when the component first renders or when the component is updated with new data). There are many lifecycle methods, but the most important ones are the invoked when a component is mounted/unmounted to the <Italic text={'DOM'} />, and when it receives new data.

Before beginning this article, I thought I'd have an easy time describing the "ins-and-outs" of <Italic text={'React'} /> in a succinct and easy-to-understand manner, but I've come to realize that there are many intricacies surrounding these features. I think it's best to look at this article as an introduction to a "framework" that's changing the way we view UI design on the web. If I've enticed your appetite, I encourage you to seek out more information about <Italic text={'React'} />. I can assure you, <Italic text={'React'} /> and its ecosystem have many more treats in store (shout out to <Italic text={'Babel'} />, <Italic text={'ES6'} />, and arrow functions).
